data.title: Searching in all files with regexp with `\n` not working as expected
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:12:01.887Z)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04 (Linux x64 4.10.0-28-generic)
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
ng-template|Ang|0.1.4
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
html-css-class-completion|Zig|1.7.0
npm-intellisense|chr|1.3.0
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.6.7
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0
Angular1|joh|0.2.0
block-travel|sas|0.0.2

(3 theme extensions excluded)

This bug exists with and without extensions enabled, however to avoid anything unexpected I am running VSCode with `$ code --disable-extensions`.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Let's assume we have opened repo directory in Explorer with some directories inside:
```
/repo
   |- /node
   |   |- /routes
   |   |   |- firstApi.js
   |   |   |- secondApi.js
   |   |   |- thirdApi.js
   |- public
```   
2. In each *Api.js file we have line:
`var m = require('../views/messages.json');`
or
`var m = require('../views/messages');`

3. I want to remove these lines, so I am right clicking _node_ directory an choosing __Find in Folder__ and trying to match regexp `.*messages.*\n?`

4. VSCode writes: `No results found in './node' - Search again in all files` and `No results found. Review your settings for configured exclusions - Open Settings` when clicking __Search again in all files__.
I also tried to set __files to include__ option to `./node/**/*.js` but it still doesn't find anything.

5. This is wrong because I can match this regexp in each file respectively by:
  * opening these files double-clicking it in Explorer (e.g. first and second Api.js files)
  * hitting *Ctrl+F* and typing the same regexp `.*messages.*\n?`

6. With _firstApi.js_ and _secondApi.js_ still opened (but _thirdApi.js_ closed) I am repeating step 3 and now it still doesn't find anything but when clicking _Search again in all files_ or searching in `./node/**/*.js` it matches proper lines only in opened files (if we close second and open third Api.js file result will be only in these files then).

7. Things are different when **I remove `\n?` from regexp** as follows: `.*messages.*`
With this changed regexp I get results in every file (with _files to include_ set to `**/*.js` or blank, with any files opened or everything closed).


The `\n?` part is important for me because I don't want to leave empty line.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

data.title: open new window at full screen
data.body:
Feature request: A way to specify the opening size/location of new windows, whether they are opened by shift-cmd-n (on Mac) or by an extension such as "Project Manager".

When I open a new window on my Mac laptop, I need all the screen I can get. I always have to manually drag the corners of OS X's default, useless mini-window to the upper left corner under the menubar and to the lower right corner of the screen. (The taskbar is permanently hidden, so it really is the lower-right corner of the screen.) I wish I could specify this state in preferences so each time I opened a window it would open in this maximally useful size/position rather than forcing me to always drag it there.

I'm NOT asking for the Mac's weird "full screen" state that creates an alternative desktop with no menu bars and doesn't work right with cmd-tab, etc. OS X totally screwed up the simple concept of "full screen" that Windows and older Macs had no trouble with, but if you want to include that as an additional option, fine, as long as "normal" fullscreen (just stretch the window under the menu bar from corner to corner) is also an option. Other options might be "default" (the current one), specific pixels (upper-left & lower-right), most-recently-closed, or whatever. All I would want would be old-fashioned "full screen" and, maybe, "specified corners" (which I might use on a jumbo monitor but might not).

Thanks. (I LOVE VS Code, BTW. I've been programming for decades, and I still need to use multiple editors, but VS Code has become my overall favorite.)

data.title: Assign keybinding to snippet
data.body:
Hi,

I usually like auto insert file header by file extension in sublime (with a plugin).
Since there is no a function full file-header extension in vscode market. And ide developer doesn't tend to add this feature (I am not asking for it) ,  I choose to use snippet instead.

But I find that, it is still not convenient to insert a snippet with out shortcut,
It would be nice to have a "shortcut" attribute for each snippet, like
```
python.json
{
    "header": {
        "prefix": "header",
        "body": [
            "# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-",
            "# @Author: mithril",
            "",
            "from __future__ import unicode_literals, print_function, absolute_import",
            ""
        ],
        "description": "python file header",
        "shortcut": "ctrl+alt+h"
    }
}
```

Once vscode detect current file extension is `.py` , then it allow to use this snippet. In this way, I can create different headers for different language with same shortcut.

data.title: Implement configuration based 'startDebugging' debug API
data.body:
Currently vscode.debug.startDebugging(nameOrConfiguration) handles only the case where the name of a configuration is passed.
Missing is the implementation for an IConfig.

data.title: Test: Extension host debugging
data.body:
Tests: #30698, #29884

- [x] win - **@egamma**
- [x] macOS - **@sandy081**
- [x] linux  - **@jrieken**

Complexity: 3

We have improved our communication between the extension host and VS Code for extension host debugging. If you do not already have a vscode extension you can generate a brand new one with the yo generator. Verify:
* You can debug an extension like before. Some [docs](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/debugging-extensions)
* You can debug an extension in a multi root workspace
* While debugging an extension make sure you can in that vscode instance reload that window, open a new folder and the debug session will still be active. If you close that window the debug session should end.
* You can debug an extension even if there are multiple vscode windows open

data.title: Smoke test: Synchronous require cannot resolve module 'electron'

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Sometimes Spectron cannot hook into Electron with the following message (_TFS build ID 30801_):

> Check dependency list! Synchronous require cannot resolve module 'electron'. This is the first mention of this module!

As a fix I have tried exposing Electron require to Spectron as per [Node Integration documentation](https://github.com/electron/spectron#node-integration) in 47794539771b5e755fe1886466af6ea0b64eece3, however it did not work. Moreover, we do not access the core Electron APIs in our tests.

This is not happening on consistent basis, therefore no idea how to reproduce.

@joaomoreno I might need your help on this.

data.title: Provide git extension interface API

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While I was trying to use parts of the git extension I noted there is no "exports" variable available when using the following snippet:

```
let gitExt = vscode.extensions.getExtension('vscode.git');
console.log(gitExt.exports);
```

Wouldn't  it be good to have such exports available for other extension developers the way it is described [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#_extensions)

Kind of an API for important git commands, like checkout, branch, commit.

data.title: Word wrap disabled when switching between plaintext and markdown tabs, have to toggle word wrap twice to re-enable it.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:08:57.197Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Go|luk|0.6.62
latex|ms-|0.1.3



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create two tabs, called Tab1 and Tab2 for reference.
2. Set Tab1 language mode to Markdown.
3. Switch to Tab2, in plaintext mode, write a line that extends past the width of window, enable Word Wrap, works as expected.
4. Switch to Tab1 (Markdown).
5. Switch to Tab2 (Plaintext). Word Wrap no longer applied.
6. Enable Word Wrap on Tab2. No effect.
7. Enable Word Wrap on Tab2 for second time. Word Wrap applied.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [Feature Request] "Special Exit" Feature That Remembers the Screen Orientations and Opened Folders
data.body:
While using vscode for complex projects, the developers usually use more than 1 window. And usually they place those windows to certain desktops (in Mac) or workspaces (in Ubuntu).

On the other hand, the nature of development requires relatively frequent restarts of physical or virtual machines.

And each restart is actually a pain since you always need to re-open all your windows and project folders one by one. And of course you need to place them to the related desktop or workspace screens.

In order to reduce that pain I suggest, if possible, a "special exit" feature so that;

1. it saves all open windows' desktop or workspace screens and their opened folders while exiting
2. and using that saved information when the vscode is opened next time, it automatically opens and orients the windows (with their opened folders) to the places that they were closed from.

data.title: The brace-expansion dependency in v1.14 contains a vulnerability
data.body:
The 1.14 release of Visual Studio Code ships with [version 1.1.6 of the brace-expansion dependency](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/npm-shrinkwrap.json#L55) which contains a [Regular Expression Denial of Service attack](https://nodesecurity.io/advisories/338) according to the node security platform. 

The solution is to upgrade `brace-expansion` to v1.1.7 or above. Since this update is a patch version, no code changes would be required as the patched version will be pulled in when VSCode gets repackaged.

- VSCode Version: *v1.14*
- OS Version: macOS Sierra *(v10.12.5)*

Steps to Reproduce:

1. clone version v.1.14 of vscode
2. install the node security platform cli: `npm install -g nsp`
3. run a security check on the module dependencies: `nsp check --output summary`

*Three vulnerabilities should be returned:*
```
Name              Installed   Patched   Path                                                                                                                                                               More Info
 brace-expansion   1.1.6       >=1.1.7   ... > chokidar@1.6.0 > ... > brace-expansion@1.1.6
 brace-expansion   1.1.6       >=1.1.7   ... > nsfw@1.0.16 > ... > brace-expansion@1.1.6
 brace-expansion   1.1.6       >=1.1.7   ... > v8-profiler@5.6.5 > ... > brace-expansion@1.1.6 
```

To confirm that the suggest fix will work, perform the following steps:

1. `rm npm-shrinkwrap.json`
2. `./scripts/npm.sh install`
3. `nsp check --output summary`

*The latest version of `brace-expansion` (currently v1.1.8) should be defined in the generated `package-lock.json` file.*

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Compiling and running c/C++ code
data.body:
I am new to vs code and have been working quite comfortably before the july update.
I tried a very basic Hello World Example and configured my Task.json and launch.json file.
I am able to build my code successfully but i am not able to view my output.
In my debug console, I see few warning messages too. I could not get that.
Help me resolve this issue.

- VSCode Version:1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Build tasks.json by Ctrl+Shift+B
2. Run the code by F5.

data.title: Could not install typing files for JavaScript language features
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1 64bit
- OS Version: Windows 7
- npm Version: 5.0.3

Steps to Reproduce: (I don't know the exact repro step, this does not repro on my Windows 10 machines)

1. Open any .js file (The following short file in my case)
   ```
   module.exports = __dirname;
   ```
2. VSCode says *Could not install typings files for JavaScript language features. Please ensure that NPM is installed or configure 'typescript.npm' in your user settings*
3. Set `typescript.npm` to `C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\npm.cmd` or `C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm.cmd` but both don't help

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature request: Pin an opened quick preview tab through tab bar
data.body:
For example, hover and click on the favicon to pin the tab.

See also https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30530#issuecomment-314857603.
